text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ADEVARUL
- Victor Romert, former head of Renel RA electricity utility was replaced by Aurel Leca, the paper says.
- The price of bread will remain unchanged despite recent increases in the price of wheat.
- The farming sector is affected by high interest rates on loans, the paper says.
- SNCFR railway authority will cut some 4,000 jobs.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Gold and copper mines in the Western Carpathians expected to reduce output following cuts in electricity supplies. Those mines allegedly failed to pay their electricity bills.
- Romanian state and private airlines should adopt a coherent strategies if they want to remain in the market and face foreign competition.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Camenco Petrovici was appointed the new head of the Casa de Economii si Consemnatiuni savings bank. He replaced Constantin Teculescu.
General:
ADEVARUL

- The Bucharest court overturned the one-year sentence imposed by a lower court on two Romanian journalists sentenced to one year in jail on charges of offending state authority in reports published last year alleging that former President Ion Iliescu had cooperated with the KGB.

- The newspaper publishes a list of villages and towns where Romanians would be affected by a change in local law proposed by the Hungarian Democratic Union asking for signs to be in both Romanian and Hungarian in places where more than 10 percent of the population belong to ethnic minorities.
- Romania's population of 22 million people fell by 300,000 over the past seven years, says a report on the country's demographic development.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI

- Radu Vasile, general secretary of the ruling National Peasant Party and deputy chairman of the upper house, the Senate, is likely to replace Virgil Magureanu as chief of the Romanian Intellience Service.
- Hundreds of files of "revolutionaries" who took part in the December 1989 popular upheaval in Brasov were found discarded at the outskirts of Bucharest.
ROMANIA LIBERA

- Romania faces three categories of crimes -- "white collar crime, that of the Gypsy mafia and that one committed by the imported mafia," said Elena Cherciu, chief prosecutor at the Bucharest's court of appeal.
- The newspaper publishes a full-page report with some of the 284 files of alleged illegal adoptions which disappeared from courts. -- Bucharest newsroom 40-1 3120264
